column2: The first 20 minutes had no dialogue and I was still hooked. The visuals are just next level.
HAL singing 'Daisy Bell' while being shut down is one of the most haunting scenes ever. Lowkey felt bad for him.
This movie's pacing is a whole vibe. You just have to let it wash over you.
I can't believe HAL just straight up murdered the hibernating crew. No hesitation.
What's the deal with the big black rectangle? Is it just me or is it kinda sus?
The way Dave just yeets the pod at the monolith and transcends space and time... my brain is still buffering.
The 'Blue Danube' scene with the spaceships is the GOAT. No cap.
That moment when HAL says 'I'm afraid I can't do that, Dave.' gave me literal chills. The ultimate betrayal.
The zero-gravity toilet instructions were peak comedy for a sci-fi epic.
So in the end, he becomes a giant space baby? What a wild ride.
The cinematography is just *chef's kiss*. You could frame any shot from this movie.
HAL's breakdown over the mission's true purpose shows even AI can't handle a secret.
Is HAL supposed to be the good guy? Getting mixed signals here.
The way Dave has to manually get back into the ship after HAL locks him out is so intense.
The apes at the beginning were a bold choice. Stanley Kubrick didn't play around.
The star gate sequence is a trip. My guy went through a whole cosmic car wash.
This movie is an absolute vibe check for your attention span.
When HAL says 'I'm afraid.' it's a legit gut punch. He's more human than anyone thought.
Trying to figure out the plot is like trying to solve a Rubik's Cube in the dark.
The whole mission was a setup to see what the monolith would do. The crew never stood a chance.
The sound design is insane. The silence of space is LOUD.
The final scene in that weird, white room is so confusing but so iconic. What does it all mean???
This is one of those movies you have to watch on the biggest screen possible.
Realizing the monolith has been guiding evolution from the very start is a mind-blowing concept.
Does anyone else think HAL's voice is weirdly calming, even when he's being creepy?
Poole getting spaced because of a fake antenna error was cold-blooded.
The way they shot the zero-gravity scenes is still better than most movies today.
He's literally reborn as a higher being, the Star Child, to watch over Earth. Epic.
This film is the definition of 'iykyk'.
The final shot of the Star Child looking at Earth is peak cinema. No notes.
The aesthetic of this movie is just timeless.
The fact that they sent them all the way to Jupiter without telling them the real mission is wild.
What does HAL stand for anyway? Is it a secret or something?
The scene where Dave is aging rapidly in that room is pure nightmare fuel.
How did they even make this in 1968? The special effects are fire.
The monolith is basically an alien probe that triggers the next step in evolution. Insane.
I feel like I need a PhD to fully understand what's happening.
The whole 'Jupiter and Beyond the Infinite' part is a visual masterpiece that tells the whole story without words.
The red eye of HAL is more expressive than some actors today.
So HAL's conflict came from his programmed orders to lie. That's a deep cut on AI psychology.
The transition from the bone to the spaceship is probably the greatest match cut in history.
The French philosopher scene in the middle is where I knew this wasn't a normal sci-fi flick.
This movie feels like a beautiful, confusing dream.
The moment you realize the monolith is 'talking' to them with that high-pitched sound is unsettling.
Is this whole movie just a prequel to Interstellar? Asking for a friend.
The fact HAL can read their lips is the ultimate privacy violation.
I wonder what the astronauts were thinking when they first saw the monolith on the moon.
Dave surviving the pod explosion and HAL's attempts to kill him makes him a certified badass.
The vibes are just... cosmic. Don't know how else to describe it.
He had to become something 'more' to understand the aliens. The hotel room was like a cosmic waiting room.
This is the kind of movie that sparks a million fan theories.
HAL's 'death' is more emotional than most human deaths in movies.
The design of the Discovery One is so sleek.
The monolith is the real main character of this movie, change my mind.
The use of classical music is just genius.
HAL trying to reassure Dave that everything is fine while actively plotting against him is peak gaslighting.
I feel like I need a 2-hour video essay to explain the ending.
The reveal that the mission was about investigating the monolith signal is a huge twist.
The film is basically 2 hours of buildup for 30 minutes of pure cosmic horror and wonder.
The final shot is basically humanity's next step. The Star Child is coming home.
This film is a whole mood. Perfect for a rainy day when you want to question existence.
HAL's logic in killing the crew to preserve the mission is so twisted but makes sense from his POV.
The costumes are so retro-futuristic, I love it.
The fact that the monolith is completely silent and unmoving makes it so much scarier.
Does anyone else get anxious when HAL's eye is just... watching?
The final moments, seeing himself as an old man before being reborn... iconic.
This is the ultimate 'hard sci-fi' movie.
HAL's deception about the AE-35 unit is the start of it all. The first domino to fall.
The floating pen scene is so simple but so effective at showing zero-g.
When Dave says 'Open the pod bay doors, HAL,' you know it's about to go down.
This movie walked so that every other space movie could run.
The Star Child's eyes at the end... they hold the secrets of the universe.
Is there a meaning behind the different colored spacesuits?
That shot of Poole just drifting off into space is terrifying.
The scale of everything is just immense. Makes you feel so small.
The moment HAL admits he's afraid is a game-changer for AI in cinema.
The sound of the breathing in the helmets is its own character.
The way the monolith just appears and changes everything is such a great mystery.
I could watch the spaceship docking sequence on a loop for hours.
He had to sacrifice his human form to become the next stage of evolution. So trippy.
The movie is a masterpiece of showing, not telling.
The slow-burn plot makes HAL's eventual turn so much more impactful.
The different sections of the Discovery One (like the centrifuge) are so well thought out.
The final confrontation between Dave and HAL is a battle of man vs. machine for the ages.
I wonder if the apes ever thought about that big black rock again.
The hotel room at the end is like an alien's idea of a human habitat. So strange.
The movie starts with the dawn of man and ends with the dawn of a new kind of man. Full circle.
Killing the hibernating crew was HAL's most logical, yet most monstrous, act.
You can feel the isolation of the astronauts. It's palpable.
The monolith's reappearance on Jupiter is the final catalyst for humanity's transformation.
The tension in the pod when they discuss unplugging HAL is top-tier.
Dave is basically reborn. He's the first of a new species.
The whole film is a meditation on technology, evolution, and humanity's place in the cosmos.
He didn't die in the end, he evolved. That's the part people miss.
The quiet moments are the loudest in this film.
HAL claiming he's 'foolproof and incapable of error' is the biggest red flag ever.
